article.description: Dedrick Finn picked up the slack on a bad shooting night for Xavier, hitting a jumper and two free throws down the stretch to guide the Musketeers to a 58-49 win over Dayton in the Atlantic 10 championship game on Saturday.
article.headline: Musketeers beat Dayton on Flyers' floor
article.linkText: Xavier completes four-game run, takes A-10
article.story: DAYTON, Ohio (AP) -- Six weeks ago, Xavier was just another team winning about as many as it was losing and headed nowhere. Now the Musketeers are on their way back to the NCAA Tournament. Dedrick Finn picked up the slack on a bad shooting night by his teammates, hitting a jumper and two free throws down the stretch to guide the Musketeers to a 58-49 win over Dayton in the Atlantic 10 championship game on Saturday. "Our backs were against the wall. There was nothing to do but play up to our ability," center Anthony Myles said of the bleak period in late January when Xavier was 10-9. "I think we did." The Musketeers (23-10), who clinched an NCAA tournament berth for the fourth year in a row, did not dominate like they had in their three previous tournament games, won by an average of 23 points. Included was a stunning 87-67 rout of No. 1-ranked Saint Joseph's in the quarterfinals. Xavier enters its 15th NCAA tournament riding a six-game win streak and having won 13 of their last 14. Finn, a sophomore reserve, scored 11 points -- none bigger than when he broke a tie at 47 with a quick 12-foot jumper off the dribble with 3:34 left that gave the Musketeers the lead for good. They had trailed by as many as seven points early in the second half. "That was a big basket," Dayton coach Brian Gregory said. "He's made some big baskets in his career. I thought we had forced him into a bad shot. What happens is they made a shot before we did." After Lionel Chalmers, voted the tournament's outstanding player, made two free throws to push the lead to four, Dayton missed two shots from the field. The Flyers (24-8) misfired on their final 11 shots from the field and didn't have a field goal over the final 8{ minutes. "We thought that we could take them out of their rhythm a little bit," Xavier coach Thad Matta said of the switch to a trapping, helping zone defense. "Marshall was starting to take the game over. We were kind of trying to slow him down." The aggressive zone didn't just shut down Marshall -- it shut down Dayton. "You roll the dice with that," Gregory said. "When we're 5-for-21 (on 3-pointers), it's a good gamble." After Chalmers' free throws, Myles followed with a basket inside off an assist from Justin Doellman for a 53-47 lead. The Flyers, the A-10's West Division champions, scored their only points of the final 7:20 on two foul shots by Ramod Marshall, who finished with 17, at the 5:47 mark. "We could not knock a shot down," Marshall said. Finn then hit two foul shots and the Musketeers made three more in the final 30 seconds to close out their third A-10 championship. Romain Sato led Xavier -- the first team to ever win four games in an A-10 tournament -- with 14 points and nine rebounds. Myles added 13 points. The Musketeers shot just 40 percent from the field but hit 17 of 21 free throws while Dayton was making just four of 10. Xavier finished with just three turnovers. Chalmers, averaging 21 points and shooting 68 percent from the field in the three previous tournament games, was limited to seven points and hit just one of seven shots from the field. Chalmers wasn't surprised that Finn picked up the Musketeers. "The key for us in all of our games is that we have guys who are making big shots and stepping up when they need to," he said. "What it comes down to is, that's why it's called a team." Sean Finn had 13 points for Dayton (24-8), which expects to collect its 13th NCAA tournament invitation. Keith Waleskowski had 11 rebounds for the Flyers. "Hopefully, our name will be called tomorrow," Gregory said. The final wasn't the matchup the A-10 might have wanted -- Xavier took care of that Thursday when they beat Saint Joseph's, never trailing and leading by as many as 37 points. Dayton broke free from a halftime tie by hitting four of its first five shots from the field -- Marshall hitting a drive and a 3-pointer -- to forge a 36-29 lead. But Xavier clawed its way back, finally pulling even at 41 by hitting six consecutive free throws. The teams were still tied at 47 after Chalmers, continuing to struggle from the field, hit two foul shots with 5:10 left. Many in the partisan crowd booed because Chalmers had to take an offbalance shot that did not hit the rim before the shot clock expired. A foul was called just as the buzzer sounded. A University of Dayton Arena capacity crowd of 13,133 -- most of them wearing red shirts to support the Flyers -- flooded the arena when the doors opened. Xavier, located less than an hour away, was represented in one small corner of the crowd and interspersed in small pockets throughout. At the end, it was the Musketeers fans who flooded the court in celebration. "This means a lot," said Sato, a quick swingman from Central African Republic. "We needed to regroup, keep focused and work hard."
